stem: Differentiate between Ulcerative Colitis (UC) and Crohn's Disease.
template: Inflammation that is continuous and limited to the mucosa of the colon is characteristic of {{disorder1}}, whereas inflammation that is transmural and can occur anywhere from the mouth to the anus is characteristic of {{disorder2}}.

rationale.correct: UC = Only Colon, Only Mucosa, Continuous. Crohn's = Mouth to Anus, All layers (Transmural), Skip lesions.
rationale.incorrect: Diverticulitis is inflammation of out-pouchings in the colon. IBS is a functional disorder without structural inflammation.
clinicalPearls: UC is cured by colectomy; Crohn's is not because it can recur anywhere in the GI tract.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Fistulas are common in Crohn's (transmural damage) but rare in UC.
